<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dm48501_1_28"> </A>


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"Black" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->


 </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> <A NAME="dm48501_item_7._management_s_discussio__ite03649"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dm48501_1"> </A>
ITEM 7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Summary  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The business segments of the Company are retail, wholesale, European and licensing operations. Information relating to these segments is summarized in
Note&nbsp;15 to the Consolidated Financial Statements. The Company believes this segment reporting reflects how its four business segments are managed and each segment's performance is evaluated.
The retail segment includes the Company's retail operations in North America. The wholesale segment includes the wholesale operations in North America and our Asian operations. The European segment
includes both wholesale and retail operations in Europe. The licensing segment includes the worldwide licensing operations of the Company. The business segments operating results exclude corporate
overhead costs, which consist of shared costs of the organization. These costs are presented separately and generally include, among other things, the following unallocated corporate costs:
information technology, human resources, accounting and finance, executive compensation, facilities and legal. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
derive our net revenue from the sale of GUESS? men's and women's apparel, MARCIANO women's apparel, G by GUESS men's and women's apparel, GUESS by MARCIANO men's and women's apparel,
and our licensees' products through our worldwide network of retail stores, wholesale customers and distributors, as well as our on-line stores. We also derive royalty revenues from
worldwide licensing activities. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unless
the context indicates otherwise, when we refer to "we," "us" or the "Company" in this Form&nbsp;10-K, we are referring to Guess?,&nbsp;Inc. and its subsidiaries on
a consolidated basis. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
January&nbsp;18, 2007, the Board of Directors of the Company approved a change in the Company's fiscal year end from December&nbsp;31 to the Saturday nearest January&nbsp;31 of
each year. The change, which
aligned the Company's reporting cycle with the National Retail Federation ("NRF") fiscal calendar and is expected to provide for more consistent year-to-year comparisons, is
effective for the Company's 2008 fiscal year. The Company's 2008 fiscal year began on February&nbsp;4, 2007 and ended on February&nbsp;2, 2008, resulting in a one-month transition
period that began January&nbsp;1, 2007 and ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. The audited results for the one month ended February&nbsp;3, 2007 are included in ITEM 15. Exhibits and Financial
Statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unless
specifically indicated otherwise, any reference to "fiscal 2008" relates to the twelve-months ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 and any reference to "fiscal 2007" relates to the
unaudited twelve months ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
purposes of this MD&amp;A, the Company has presented the financial performance comparison of the 2008 fiscal year versus the 2007 fiscal year. The Company has also presented the
financial performance between the one-month audited transition period ended February&nbsp;3, 2007 and the comparable one-month unaudited period ended January&nbsp;28, 2006.
Finally, the Company has presented the financial performance between the twelve-months ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and the twelve-months ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fiscal
years 2008 and 2007 include 52&nbsp;weeks and 53&nbsp;weeks, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company reports NRF calendar comparable store sales on a quarterly basis for its full-price retail and factory outlet stores in the U.S. and Canada. A store is considered
comparable after it has been open for 13 full months. If a store remodel results in a square footage change of more than 15%, or involves a relocation or a change in store concept, the store is
removed from the comparable store base until it has been opened at its new size, in its new location or under its new concept for 13 full months. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>28</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=31,EFW="2183334",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=170332,FOLIO='28',FILE='DISK108:[08ZAF1.08ZAF48501]DM48501A.;7',USER='ABEAULI',CD=';1-APR-2008;14:09' -->
<A NAME="page_dm48501_1_29"> </A>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Executive Summary  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>The Company  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's operations generated net earnings of $186.5&nbsp;million, or diluted earnings of $1.99 per share, for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008,
compared to net earnings of $131.2&nbsp;million, or diluted earnings of $1.42 per share, for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total
net revenues increased 39.7% to $1,749.9&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from $1,252.7&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. All of
our business segments contributed to this growth. The European segment was the largest contributor to the growth in revenues representing roughly half of the consolidated revenue growth. The revenue
growth also reflected higher comparable store sales and retail store expansion in the retail segment. In addition, our wholesale segment increased revenues, driven by our new South Korea operation and
stronger product performance in our North American wholesale business, while our licensing business increased revenues across all key accessories categories and footwear. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross
margin increased 120 basis points to 45.3% for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to the same prior year period. The improvement in the overall gross margin was
attributable to a higher mix of European net revenues, which generated a relatively higher gross margin than the other businesses, higher mark-ups in our wholesale segment, higher product
margins in our retail segment and the recognition of gift card breakage. This improvement was partially offset by the lower product margin in Europe. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Selling,
general and administrative ("SG&amp;A") expenses increased 39.4% to $483.6&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 compared to $347.0&nbsp;million for the year
ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. This increase in SG&amp;A expenses was driven by investments in our new businesses, higher variable costs to support the higher sales in our existing businesses, higher
performance-based expenses and investments in infrastructure in Europe. As a percentage of revenues, SG&amp;A expense decreased 10 basis points to 27.6% for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008,
compared to the prior-year. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Overall,
the higher gross margin and the decrease in SG&amp;A spending as a percentage of net revenues, resulted in an increase in the Company's operating margin to 17.7% for the year ended
February&nbsp;2, 2008, up 130 basis points from 16.4% for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
interest income increased $4.1&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 primarily due to the early redemption of the Company's 6.75% secured notes of
$32.8&nbsp;million at the end of 2006 and higher average invested cash balances. The Secured Notes were redeemed in December 2006 resulting in $1.9&nbsp;million related to the
write-off of debt issuance costs and payment of redemption premium, which are included in interest expense for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
expense was $1.8&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, versus other income of $4.7&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. Other expense in
the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 was primarily due to net losses related to changes in foreign exchange rates on forward contracts and other foreign currency transactions. Other income in the
prior year period comprised gains on sale of land and other long-term investments. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
effective income tax rate increased 260 basis points to 39.8% for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 compared to 37.2% in the prior year primarily due to a higher mix of profits
in higher tax jurisdictions and a change to the Italian tax rate effective in fiscal 2009 that unfavorably impacted our net deferred tax asset position at the end of fiscal 2008. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company had $275.6&nbsp;million in cash and cash equivalents as of February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to $207.6&nbsp;million as of February&nbsp;3, 2007. Total debt, including
capital lease obligations, as of February&nbsp;2, 2008, was $54.0&nbsp;million, up $15.9&nbsp;million from $38.1&nbsp;million as of February&nbsp;3, 2007. The increase in debt was driven
primarily by the increase in short-term borrowings from GUESS? Europe. Accounts receivable </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>29</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=32,EFW="2183334",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=853833,FOLIO='29',FILE='DISK108:[08ZAF1.08ZAF48501]DM48501A.;7',USER='ABEAULI',CD=';1-APR-2008;14:09' -->
<A NAME="page_dm48501_1_30"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>increased
by $111.7&nbsp;million, or 78.3%, to $254.4&nbsp;million at February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to $142.7&nbsp;million at February&nbsp;3, 2007. The increase in accounts receivable
primarily supported the revenue growth in Europe, South Korea and Greater China. Accounts receivable also increased due to the acquisition of BARN in January 2008. Currency translation fluctuations
accounted for $24.3&nbsp;million of the increase in accounts receivable. Inventory increased by $58.5&nbsp;million, or 33.7%, to $232.2&nbsp;million as of February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to
$173.7&nbsp;million as of February&nbsp;3, 2007. Approximately $31.0&nbsp;million of this increase was attributable to new businesses including Focus, BARN, our new South Korea operation, our
Mexico and Greater China operations and our new G by GUESS store concept. The remaining inventory increase was related to anticipated sales growth in our existing European and North American
operations. Currency fluctuations resulted in a higher translation impact on the current year's ending inventory of approximately $15.7&nbsp;million compared to the year ago amount. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Retail  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our retail segment, comprising North American full-priced retail and factory outlet stores and e-commerce, generated net sales of
$862.4&nbsp;million during the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, an increase of 16.4% from $741.1&nbsp;million in the prior year period. This growth was driven by a comparable store sales
increase of 14.6% and a larger store base, which represented a net 5.3% increase in average square footage compared to the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. All of our product categories contributed
to this growth. Retail earnings from operations increased by $23.0&nbsp;million to $128.5&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to $105.5&nbsp;million for the year
ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. This increase was primarily driven by higher sales volume, higher product margin and occupancy leverage, partially offset by increased investments in infrastructure to
support our new G by GUESS brand concept and higher advertising expense. Operating margin increased 70 basis points to 14.9% in the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to 14.2% in the year
ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, we opened 49 new stores and closed ten underperforming stores in the U.S. and Canada. At February&nbsp;2, 2008, we operated 373 stores in the
U.S. and Canada, comprised of 187 full-priced retail stores, 97 factory outlet stores, 38&nbsp;Marciano stores, 17 GUESS? Accessories stores and 34 G by GUESS stores. This compares to
334 stores as of February&nbsp;3, 2007. We have continued to develop our new concept stores, which includes our Marciano branded stores and our G by GUESS stores, and we believe that over time these
concepts can grow to become significant chains in North America. The MARCIANO brand, a contemporary line that commands higher price points, is also available in approximately a quarter of our
full-price GUESS? retail stores in the U.S. and Canada. G by GUESS, which launched in early 2007, is a new brand and store concept that offers a full line of apparel for women and men and
a full line of accessories and footwear to support the lifestyle of this customer and is aimed to capture a market demographic that is younger and shops price points between our factory and
full-priced retail stores. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Wholesale  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Wholesale segment revenues increased by $105.8&nbsp;million, or 69.3%, to $258.4&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from
$152.6&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. The increase in net revenues was primarily due to international expansion, including South Korea (which we began to operate directly
in January 2007), coupled with growth in the North American wholesale business. Earnings from operations for the wholesale segment improved by $24.7&nbsp;million, or 98.3%, to $49.9&nbsp;million
for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from $25.2&nbsp;million for the prior year period. This improvement was driven by increased sales in Asia and North America and higher gross margin as a
result of higher mark-ups in the North American wholesale business, partially offset by increased spending on infrastructure to support the growth of the new businesses in Asia. Operating
margin increased 280 basis points to 19.3% in the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to 16.5% for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>30</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=33,EFW="2183334",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=840869,FOLIO='30',FILE='DISK108:[08ZAF1.08ZAF48501]DM48501A.;7',USER='ABEAULI',CD=';1-APR-2008;14:09' -->
<A NAME="page_dm48501_1_31"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Europe  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In Europe, revenues increased by $246.6&nbsp;million, or 84.5%, to $538.4&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to
$291.8&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. The majority of the revenue growth was generated by the European wholesale business, driven by growth in both our existing accessories
and apparel businesses and our acquisition of a 75% equity interest in Focus on December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company's licensee for GUESS by MARCIANO contemporary apparel for women and men in Europe,
the Middle East and Asia. In addition, at February&nbsp;2, 2008, we directly operated 40 stores in Europe, which includes the four stores acquired as part of the Focus acquisition, compared to 24
stores in the prior year. Earnings from operations from our European segment increased by $47.6&nbsp;million, or 65.1%, to $120.8&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from
$73.2&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. Operating margin decreased 270 basis points to 22.4%
in the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to 25.1% for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007 due to lower product margin and increased spending to support the growth of our infrastructure
in the European region, including our investment in the new European headquarters based in Lugano, Switzerland. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Licensing  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our licensing business revenues increased by $23.6&nbsp;million, or 35.1%, to $90.7&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from
$67.1&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. This increase was driven by growth in sales of several product categories, especially handbags, footwear and watches, and the increased
recognition of licensing revenues as a result of the amortization of fixed cash rights payments received from licensees in connection with previously renegotiated contracts based on the periods these
contracts represent. The increase in net royalties was partially offset by the loss of royalty revenue from our GUESS by MARCIANO and South Korean licensees, both of which we now operate directly and
are, therefore, no longer a part of the licensing segment. Licensing segment earnings from operations increased $19.3&nbsp;million, or 32.9%, to $77.9&nbsp;million for the year ended
February&nbsp;2, 2008, from $58.7&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. Operating margin decreased 150 basis points to 85.9% for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 compared
to 87.4% for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007 due to higher spending in advertising and higher performance based compensation expense for the year compared to the prior year period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Outside
of the U.S. and Canada, in the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, together with our partners we opened 184 new stores, including 83 in Europe, 93 in Asia and eight stores in
Mexico, Central and South America. We ended the year with 579 stores outside of the U.S. and Canada, of which 421 were GUESS? stores, 36 were GUESS by MARCIANO stores, and 122 were GUESS? Accessories
stores. Of the 579 stores, 60 were operated by the Company and 519 were operated by licensees or distributors. This store count does not include 82 jean and accessory concessions located in South
Korea and China because of their smaller store size in relation to our standard international store size. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Corporate Overhead  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Corporate overhead increased by $11.0&nbsp;million, or 19.3%, to $68.0&nbsp;million in the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from $57.0&nbsp;million for
the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. This increase was primarily due to increased performance-based compensation costs, including share based payment expense. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Application of Critical Accounting Policies  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Consolidated Financial Statements are prepared in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the U.S., which require management to make
estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of the assets and liabilities and disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities as of the date of the financial statements and the
reported amounts of revenue and expenses during the reporting period. Management bases its estimates and judgments on its historical experience and other </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>31</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=34,EFW="2183334",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=928496,FOLIO='31',FILE='DISK108:[08ZAF1.08ZAF48501]DM48501A.;7',USER='ABEAULI',CD=';1-APR-2008;14:09' -->
<A NAME="page_dm48501_1_32"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>relevant
factors, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. Management evaluates
its estimates and judgments on an ongoing basis including those related to the valuation of inventories, accounts receivable allowances, sales return allowances, the useful life of assets for
depreciation, restructuring expense and accruals, evaluation of impairment, recoverability of deferred taxes, workers compensation accruals, litigation accruals, pension obligations and stock-based
compensation. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company believes that the following significant accounting policies involve a higher degree of judgment and complexity. In addition to the accounting policies mentioned below, see
Note&nbsp;1 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for other significant accounting policies. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Accounts receivable reserves  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the normal course of business, the Company grants credit directly to certain wholesale customers after a credit analysis based on financial and other criteria
is performed. Accounts receivable are recorded net of an allowance for doubtful accounts. The Company maintains allowances for doubtful accounts for estimated losses that result from the inability of
its wholesale customers to make their required payments. The Company bases its allowances through analysis of the aging of accounts receivable at the date of the financial statements, assessments of
historical collection trends and an evaluation of the impact of current economic conditions. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Costs
associated with customer markdowns are recorded as a reduction to net revenues, and are included in the allowance for accounts receivable. Historically, these markdown allowances
resulted from seasonal negotiations with the Company's wholesale customers, as well as historical trends and the evaluation of the impact of the economic conditions. During fiscal 2008, the Company
renegotiated its arrangements with its major customers in the U.S. to fix the percentage of sales that will be expensed as markdown allowances. The negotiation of a fixed rate allows the Company to
process credit memos against the outstanding balance immediately which has resulted in a reduction of our outstanding markdown allowance accrual relative to the prior year. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Sales returns reserves  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company accrues for estimated sales returns in the period in which the related revenue is recognized. To recognize the financial impact of sales returns, the
Company estimates the amount of goods that will be returned based on historical experience and reduces sales and cost of sales accordingly based on historical return experience. The Company's policy
allows retail customers a 30&nbsp;day period to return merchandise following the date of sale. Substantially all of these returns are considered to be resalable at a price that exceeds the cost of
the merchandise. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Inventory reserves  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Inventories are valued at the lower of cost (primarily weighted average method) or market. The Company continually evaluates its inventories by assessing slow
moving product as well as prior seasons' inventory. Market value of aged inventory is estimated based on historical sales trends for this category of inventory of the Company's individual product
lines, the impact of market trends, an evaluation of economic conditions and the value of current orders relating to the future sales of this type of inventory. The Company closely monitors its
off-price sales to ensure the actual results closely match initial estimates. Estimates are regularly updated based upon this continuing review. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Valuation of goodwill, intangible and other long-lived assets  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company assesses the impairment of its long-lived assets (i.e.,&nbsp;goodwill, intangible assets and property and equipment), which requires the
Company to make assumptions and judgments regarding the carrying value of these assets on an annual basis, or more frequently if events or changes in circumstances </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>32</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=35,EFW="2183334",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=266492,FOLIO='32',FILE='DISK108:[08ZAF1.08ZAF48501]DM48501A.;7',USER='ABEAULI',CD=';1-APR-2008;14:09' -->
<A NAME="page_dm48501_1_33"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>indicate
that the assets might be impaired. An asset is considered to be impaired if the Company determines that the carrying value may not be recoverable based upon its assessment of the asset's
ability to continue to generate income from operations and positive cash flow in future periods or if significant changes in the Company's strategic business objectives and utilization of the assets
occurred. If the assets (other than goodwill) are assessed to be recoverable, they are depreciated or amortized over the periods benefited. If the assets are considered to be impaired, the impairment
recognized is the amount by which the carrying value of the assets exceeds the fair value of those assets. Fair value is determined based upon the discounted cash flows derived from the underlying
asset. See Note&nbsp;1 of the Consolidated Financial Statements for further discussion. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Pension benefit plan actuarial assumptions  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's pension obligations and related costs are calculated using actuarial concepts, within the framework of the amendment of Statement of Financial
Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;87 "Employer's Accounting for Pensions." The discount rate is an important element of expense and/or liability measurement. We evaluate this critical assumption
annually which enables us to state expected future payments for benefits as a present value on the measurement date. Refer to Note&nbsp;10 for Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan related
information. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Litigation reserves  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Estimated amounts for claims that are probable and can be reasonably estimated are recorded as liabilities in our consolidated balance sheet. The likelihood of a
material change in these estimated reserves would be dependent on new claims as they may arise and the favorable or unfavorable outcome of the particular litigation. Both the amount and range of loss
on any remaining pending litigation is uncertain. As additional information becomes available, the Company will assess the potential liability related to pending litigation and will revise estimates
as appropriate. Such revisions in estimates of the potential liability could materially impact the results of operations and financial position. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Stock-based compensation  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective January&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company adopted the fair value recognition provisions of SFAS&nbsp;123R using the modified prospective transition method.
Under this method, compensation cost recognized for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 included: (a)&nbsp;compensation expense for all stock-based payments granted prior to, but not yet vested
as of, December&nbsp;31, 2005, based on the grant date fair value estimated in accordance with the original provisions of SFAS&nbsp;123, "Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation," ("FAS123") and
(b)&nbsp;compensation expense for all stock-based payments granted on or after January&nbsp;1, 2006, based on the grant date fair value estimated in accordance with the provisions of
SFAS&nbsp;123R. The fair value of each stock option is estimated on the grant date using the Black-Scholes option-pricing model with the following weighted-average assumptions used for new grants.
The risk-free interest rate is based on the U.S. Treasury yield curve in effect for the expected term of the option at the time of grant. The expected volatility is determined based on an
average of both historical volatility and implied volatility. Implied volatility is derived from exchange traded options on the Company's common stock. The expected life used prior to November 2007
was based on the "simplified" method described in the SEC Staff Accounting Bulletin No.&nbsp;107. For options granted beginning November 2007, the expected term is determined based on historical
trends. The dividend yield for the one month period ended February&nbsp;3, 2007 and prior years was zero. In the first quarter of fiscal 2008, the Board of Directors authorized and approved the
initiation of a quarterly dividend. The expected forfeiture rate is determined based on historical data. Compensation expense for new stock
options and nonvested stock awards is recognized on a straight-line basis over the vesting period. In accordance with the modified prospective transition method, results for prior periods
have not been restated. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>33</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=36,EFW="2183334",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=605936,FOLIO='33',FILE='DISK108:[08ZAF1.08ZAF48501]DM48501A.;7',USER='ABEAULI',CD=';1-APR-2008;14:09' -->
<A NAME="page_dm48501_1_34"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Taxes  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company adopted FASB Interpretation 48 ("FIN&nbsp;48"), Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes, in January 2007. FIN&nbsp;48 clarifies the accounting
for uncertainty in income taxes recognized in an enterprise's financial statements in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;109 and prescribes a recognition threshold and measurement attribute for the financial
statement recognition and measurement of a tax position taken or expected to be taken in a tax return. FIN&nbsp;48 also provides guidance on derecognition, classification, interest and penalties,
accounting in interim periods, disclosure, and transition. The adoption of FIN&nbsp;48 did not have a material impact on the Company's financial position and results of operations. The Company's
continuing practice is to recognize interest and penalties related to income tax matters in income tax expense. See Note&nbsp;9 to the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements for further
information regarding the adoption of FIN&nbsp;48. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Hedge Accounting  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company operates in foreign countries, which exposes it to market risk associated with foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations. The Company has entered
into certain forward contracts and swaps to hedge the risk of foreign currency rate fluctuations. The Company has elected to apply the hedge accounting rules as required by SFAS No.&nbsp;133
("SFAS&nbsp;133"), "Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities," for certain of these hedges. The Company's objective is to hedge the variability in forecasted cash flow due to the
foreign currency risk (USD/Canadian exchange rate) associated with certain anticipated inventory purchases on a first dollar basis for specific months. Changes in the fair value of forward contracts
designated as cash-flow hedges are recorded as a component of accumulated other comprehensive earnings within stockholders' equity, and are recognized in cost of goods sold in the period
which approximates the time the hedged merchandise inventory is sold. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company has foreign currency contracts that are not designated as hedges for accounting purposes. Changes in fair value of foreign currency contracts not qualifying as cash flow
hedges are reported in net earnings as part of other income and expenses. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Gift Card Breakage  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company completed its analysis of unredeemed electronic gift card liabilities in the quarter ended August&nbsp;4, 2007 for the U.S. retail business. Gift
card breakage is income recognized due to the non-redemption of a portion of gift cards sold by the Company for which a liability was recorded in prior periods. Beginning with the quarter
ended August&nbsp;4, 2007, these amounts are accounted for under the redemption recognition method and are classified as additional net revenues as the gift cards are redeemed. The Company
determined a gift card breakage rate of approximately 6.5% in the quarter ended August&nbsp;4, 2007 based upon historical redemption patterns, which represented the cumulative estimated amount of
gift card breakage from the inception of the electronic gift card program in late 2002. Based upon historical redemption trends, the Company recognizes estimated gift card breakage as a component of
net revenue in proportion to actual gift card redemptions, over the period that remaining gift card values are redeemed. As of February&nbsp;2, 2008, the Company has recognized $3.5&nbsp;million
gift card breakage to revenue, of which $3.1&nbsp;million, or $0.02 per diluted share, was a one-time cumulative adjustment recognized in the quarter ended August&nbsp;4, 2007. Any
future revisions to the estimated breakage rate may result in changes in the amount of breakage income recognized in future periods. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>34</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Year Ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 Compared to Year Ended February&nbsp;3, 2007.  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>NET REVENUE.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Net revenue for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 increased by $497.2&nbsp;million, or 39.7%, to
$1,749.9&nbsp;million, from $1,252.7&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. All segments contributed to this revenue growth with double-digit percentage increases. The largest
contribution to this revenue growth was generated by our European segment. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from retail operations increased by $121.3&nbsp;million, or 16.4%, to $862.4&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from $741.1&nbsp;million for the
year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. The increase was driven by a comparable store sales growth of 14.6% and an average of 26 net additional stores during the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008
resulting in a 5.3% increase in average square footage compared to the
prior year period. Currency translation fluctuations accounted for $14.3&nbsp;million of the increase in net revenue relating to our Canadian retail stores. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from wholesale operations increased by $105.8&nbsp;million, or 69.3%, to $258.4&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from $152.6&nbsp;million for
the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. Approximately 80.0% of this revenue growth was generated outside of the U.S., primarily in Asia. Our North American wholesale net revenue growth was primarily
attributable to strong product performance. Our products were sold in the U.S. in approximately 1,006 major doors as of February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to 961 major doors at the end of the prior
year period. Currency translation fluctuations accounted for $2.8&nbsp;million of the increase in net revenue relating to our Canadian wholesale business. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from European operations increased by $246.6&nbsp;million, or 84.5%, to $538.4&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from $291.8&nbsp;million for the
year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. The majority of the revenue growth was generated by the European wholesale business, driven by our continued growth in both our existing accessories and apparel
businesses and our acquisition of a 75% equity interest in Focus on December&nbsp;31, 2006. The growth is also attributable to same store sales growth in our existing retail </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>35</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=38,EFW="2183334",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=856352,FOLIO='35',FILE='DISK108:[08ZAF1.08ZAF48501]DO48501A.;15',USER='ABEAULI',CD=';1-APR-2008;13:42' -->
<A NAME="page_do48501_1_36"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>stores
and the addition of new retail stores. Currency translation fluctuations accounted for $48.1&nbsp;million of the increase in net revenue relating to our European operations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
royalty revenue from licensing operations increased by $23.6&nbsp;million, or 35.1%, to $90.7&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from $67.1&nbsp;million
for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. The increase was the result of the strength of the accessories business, particularly handbags, footwear and watches, and the increased recognition of
licensing revenues as a result of the amortization of fixed cash rights payments received from licensees in connection with previously renegotiated contracts based on the periods these contracts
represent. Licensing revenues in the current year did not include any royalty revenue from our GUESS by MARCIANO and South Korean licensees, both of which we now operate directly, as the associated
sales are now reported as revenue in the European and wholesale segments, respectively. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>GROSS PROFIT.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Gross profit increased by $240.3&nbsp;million, or 43.5%, to $792.8&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2,
2008, from $552.5&nbsp;million in the prior period. The increase in gross profit primarily resulted from sales growth in all segments. </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross
profit for the retail segment increased by $50.2&nbsp;million, or 17.9%, to $330.1&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from
$279.9&nbsp;million in the prior period, primarily due to higher sales volume and higher average selling prices, partially offset by higher occupancy costs.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross
profit for the wholesale segment increased by $44.1&nbsp;million, or 79.6%, to $99.4&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from
$55.3&nbsp;million in the prior year period, primarily due to the increase in sales volume in Asia, and increased sales and higher mark-ups in North America driven by stronger product
performance.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross
profit for the European operations increased by $122.4&nbsp;million, or 81.5%, to $272.6&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from
$150.2&nbsp;million in the prior year period. The European gross profit increase resulted from higher sales volumes in the existing European operations and the acquisition of a 75% equity interest
in Focus at the end of 2006.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Gross
profit for the licensing segment increased by $23.6&nbsp;million, or 35.1%, to $90.7&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from
$67.1&nbsp;million in the prior year period. The licensing gross profit improvement was primarily the result of the strong sales performance of accessories, especially handbags, footwear and
watches. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross
margin (gross profit as a percentage of total net revenues) increased 120 basis points to 45.3% for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from 44.1% for the year ended
February&nbsp;3, 2007. The improvement in the overall gross margin was attributable to a higher mix of European net revenues, which generated a relatively higher gross margin than the other
businesses, higher mark-ups in our wholesale segment, and higher product margins in our retail segment due to higher mark-ups and gift card breakage income. This improvement
was partially offset by the lower product margin in Europe compared to the prior year. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's gross margin may not be comparable to other entities since some entities include all of the costs related to their distribution in cost of product sales and others, like
the Company, exclude the wholesale related distribution costs from gross margin, including them instead in selling, general and administrative expenses. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>SELLING, GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>SG&amp;A expenses increased by $136.6&nbsp;million, or 39.4%, to $483.6&nbsp;million for the
year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, from $347.0&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. Approximately $68.0&nbsp;million of the increase was attributable to incremental spending
required to support new businesses including Focus, our new European headquarters in Lugano, Switzerland, the new G by GUESS brand initiative, the South Korea operation, expansion in Greater China and
Mexico, and BARN in Europe. In addition, the increase was also attributable to growth in store selling, merchandising and distribution costs of $41.8&nbsp;million, incremental compensation expenses
(primarily performance-based) of $12.5&nbsp;million, and additional advertising and marketing spending in our </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>36</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=39,EFW="2183334",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=335751,FOLIO='36',FILE='DISK108:[08ZAF1.08ZAF48501]DO48501A.;15',USER='ABEAULI',CD=';1-APR-2008;13:42' -->
<A NAME="page_do48501_1_37"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>existing
businesses of $8.3&nbsp;million. As a percentage of net revenue, SG&amp;A expenses improved to 27.6% for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to 27.7% for the prior year period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>EARNINGS FROM OPERATIONS.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations increased by $103.6&nbsp;million, or 50.4%, to $309.1&nbsp;million for the year
ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared with earnings from operations of $205.5&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings
from operations for the retail segment were $128.5&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to earnings from operations of
$105.5&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. The increase in earnings from operations for the retail segment was driven by the higher sales volume, higher product margin and
occupancy leverage, partially offset by increased investments in infrastructure to support our new G by GUESS brand concept and higher advertising expense. Currency translation fluctuations accounted
for $3.5&nbsp;million of the increase in earnings from operations for our Canadian retail stores.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings
from operations for the wholesale segment were $49.9&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to earnings from operations of
$25.2&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. This increase was principally due to incremental sales and gross profit from our new South Korea operation and higher sales and
improved gross profit in North America, partially offset by additional SG&amp;A expenses in Asia, including South Korea, to build infrastructure in this region and support the increased sales. Currency
translation fluctuations accounted for $0.8&nbsp;million of the increase in earnings from operations for our Canadian wholesale business.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings
from operations for the European segment were $120.8&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to $73.2&nbsp;million for the year ended
February&nbsp;3, 2007. The increase was primarily due to higher sales and gross profit in the existing accessories and apparel wholesale businesses combined with the sales and gross profit resulting
from our acquisition of a 75% equity interest in Focus in late 2006. In addition, our existing Company-owned retail business in Europe continued to improve, generating strong sales growth and
increasing profits. The growth in sales and gross profit was partially offset by higher volume related and infrastructure expansion expenses.
Currency translation fluctuations accounted for $10.4&nbsp;million of the increase in earnings from operations for our European operations.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings
from operations for the licensing segment were $77.9&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to $58.7&nbsp;million for the year ended
February&nbsp;3, 2007. The improvement was the result of higher revenues generated by our accessories product licensees and the recognition of additional licensing revenues relating to the
amortization of fixed cash rights payments received from licensees in connection with previously renegotiated contracts. These increases were partially offset by the loss of royalty revenue from the
GUESS by MARCIANO and South Korean licensees in the period compared to the prior year period.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Unallocated
corporate overhead was $68.0&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to $57.0&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3,
2007, mainly due to higher performance-based compensation costs, including share based payment expense. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
higher gross margin and lower SG&amp;A spending as a percentage of net revenues resulted in an increase in operating margin of 130 basis points to 17.7% for the year ended
February&nbsp;2, 2008 from 16.4% for the prior year period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>INTEREST EXPENSE AND INTEREST INCOME.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Interest expense decreased to $3.4&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008,
compared to $7.7&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007, primarily due to the early redemption of the Company's 6.75% secured notes of $32.8&nbsp;million at the end of 2006. The
Secured Notes were redeemed in December 2006 resulting in a $1.4&nbsp;million write-off of debt issuance costs and a $0.5&nbsp;million redemption premium, which are included in
interest expense for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. On a comparable basis, the average debt balance for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>37</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=40,EFW="2183334",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=760622,FOLIO='37',FILE='DISK108:[08ZAF1.08ZAF48501]DO48501A.;15',USER='ABEAULI',CD=';1-APR-2008;13:42' -->
<A NAME="page_do48501_1_38"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>was
$48.6&nbsp;million versus an average debt balance of $79.4&nbsp;million, for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. Interest income increased to $7.5&nbsp;million for the year ended
February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to $6.2&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007, due to higher average invested cash balances. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>OTHER INCOME, NET.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Other expense was $1.8&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, versus income of $4.7&nbsp;million
for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. Other expense in the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 was primarily due to net losses related to changes in foreign exchange rates on forward contracts
and other foreign currency transactions. Other income in the prior year period comprised gains on sale of land and other long-term investments. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>INCOME TAXES.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Income tax expense for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 was $124.1&nbsp;million, or a 39.8% effective tax rate,
compared to income tax expense of $77.6&nbsp;million, or a 37.2% effective tax rate, for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. This year's higher tax rate was due to a higher mix of profits in
higher tax jurisdictions, the utilization of capital loss carryforwards in the prior year, favorable tax audit settlements last year and a recent decline in the Italian statutory tax rate, effective
in fiscal 2009, that resulted in a devaluation of deferred tax assets in the current year. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>MINORITY INTEREST.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>The minority interest expense of $0.9&nbsp;million, net of taxes, primarily represents the portion of earnings of
Focus for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 allocated to the minority interest shareholders. The Company acquired a 75% interest in Focus on December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>NET EARNINGS.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Net earnings increased by $55.3&nbsp;million, or 42.2%, to $186.5&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2,
2008, from $131.2&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. Diluted earnings per share increased to $1.99 per share for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 compared to $1.42 per
share for the year ended February&nbsp;3, 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>One-Month Audited Transition Period Ended February&nbsp;3, 2007 ("January 2007") Compared to the One-Month Unaudited Period Ended January&nbsp;28,
2006 ("January 2006").  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company reported net earnings of $8.0&nbsp;million, or diluted earnings of $0.09 per share, for January 2007 (which included 34&nbsp;days), compared to
$0.00 per share for January 2006 (which included 28&nbsp;days). Net revenue for January 2007 increased by $67.5&nbsp;million, or 98.6%, to $136.0&nbsp;million, from $68.5&nbsp;million for
January 2006. Gross profit increased by $33.1&nbsp;million, or 146.6%, to $55.7&nbsp;million for January 2007, from $22.6&nbsp;million for January 2006. SG&amp;A expenses increased by
$20.6&nbsp;million, or 91.2%, to $43.3&nbsp;million for January 2007, from $22.6&nbsp;million for January 2006. Earnings from operations increased by $12.5&nbsp;million to $12.5&nbsp;million
for January 2007, compared to the approximately break-even results from operations for January 2006. These results reflect the impact of the significant growth in our existing European
operations, the comparable store sales growth of 12.7% in our retail store operations in North America for January 2007 compared to the prior-year period, the greater number of days in the
one month ended January 2007 compared to the prior-year period and the acquisition of a 75% majority interest in Focus, our European GUESS by MARCIANO licensee, in late 2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Year Ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 Compared to Year Ended December&nbsp;31, 2005.  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>NET REVENUE.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Net revenue increased $249.1&nbsp;million, or 26.6%, to $1,185.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006,
from $936.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. All segments contributed to this growth, with the largest contributions from our retail and European segments. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from retail operations increased $108.4&nbsp;million, or 17.7%, to $721.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, from $612.9&nbsp;million for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. The increase was driven by sales for stores that were open for more than one year which grew 12.8% and accounted for $67.9&nbsp;million of the increase and a
$40.5&nbsp;million increase due to an average of 24 net new stores during 2006 with a 5.3% increase in average square footage compared to 2005. While the majority of this $67.9&nbsp;million
increase was generated in our U.S. stores, the most significant store sales rate increases were </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>38</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=41,EFW="2183334",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=320750,FOLIO='38',FILE='DISK108:[08ZAF1.08ZAF48501]DO48501A.;15',USER='ABEAULI',CD=';1-APR-2008;13:42' -->
<A NAME="page_do48501_1_39"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>in
our Canadian retail stores. Currency fluctuations accounted for $7.5&nbsp;million of the increase in net revenue relating to our Canadian retail stores. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from wholesale operations increased $25.2&nbsp;million, or 20.8%, to $146.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, from $121.1&nbsp;million for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. U.S. wholesale net revenue increased $16.4&nbsp;million, or 19.4%, to $101.1&nbsp;million in 2006 from $84.7&nbsp;million in 2005. The increase in U.S.
wholesale revenue was primarily attributable to strong product performance which drove higher sales volume and lower markdown allowances as a percentage of revenue. Our products were sold domestically
in approximately 970 and 965 major doors at the end of 2006 and 2005, respectively. Approximately 44.7% of this revenue growth was generated outside of the U.S., primarily in Asia. Currency
fluctuations accounted for $1.5&nbsp;million of the increase in net revenue relating to our Canadian wholesale business. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenue from European operations increased $98.6&nbsp;million, or 64.1%, to $252.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, from $153.8&nbsp;million for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. The increase was due to growth in our accessories and footwear businesses, higher sales in our apparel wholesale business, and additional sales in our owned retail
stores. Currency fluctuations accounted for $1.1&nbsp;million of the increase in net revenue relating to our European operations. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
royalties from licensing operations increased by $16.9&nbsp;million, or 35.0%, to $65.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, from $48.3&nbsp;million for
the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. The increase was the result of the strength of the accessories business, particularly handbags, watches, and the impact of incremental sales from our new
footwear and fragrance licensees. The number of licensees remained consistent in 2006 as compared to 2005. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>GROSS PROFIT.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Gross profit increased $138.5&nbsp;million, or 36.4%, to $519.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006,
from $380.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. The increase in gross profit primarily resulted from increased sales in all segments and improved gross margin in the European,
wholesale and retail segments. Gross profit for the retail segment increased $55.5&nbsp;million, or
26.0%, to $269.4&nbsp;million primarily due to higher retail sales volumes and higher margins due to increases in average selling price partially offset by the additional occupancy cost of operating
an incremental average 24 net new stores. Gross profit for the wholesale segment increased $12.8&nbsp;million, or 32.4%, to $52.4&nbsp;million as a result of increased sales volume and lower
markdown allowances. Gross profit for our European operations increased $53.2&nbsp;million to $132.4&nbsp;million primarily attributable to the increase in sales. Higher licensing revenue
increased overall gross profit by $17.0&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross
margin (gross profit as a percentage of total net revenues) increased 310 basis points to 43.8% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, from 40.7% for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2005. The improvement in the overall gross margin was attributable to a higher mix of European and licensing segment revenues, both of which generate higher gross margin than our
retail and wholesale segments. Gross margin improved in both Europe and retail due to better product margins and improved occupancy leverage. Gross margin improved in our wholesale business, due
mainly to lower markdown allowances. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's gross margins may not be comparable to other entities since some entities include all of the costs related to their distribution in cost of product sales and others, like
the Company, exclude the wholesale related distribution costs from gross margin, including them instead in selling, general and administrative expenses. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>SELLING, GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>SG&amp;A expenses increased $47.3&nbsp;million, or 16.9%, to $326.4&nbsp;million for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, from $279.1&nbsp;million, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. The increase was primarily attributable to a $17.1&nbsp;million increase in our European
operations driven by selling and distribution costs, growth in North America for store selling, merchandising and distribution costs of $12.9&nbsp;million, incremental compensation expenses
(primarily performance-based) of $13.5&nbsp;million, and additional advertising and marketing spending in our existing </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>39</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=42,EFW="2183334",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=325085,FOLIO='39',FILE='DISK108:[08ZAF1.08ZAF48501]DO48501A.;15',USER='ABEAULI',CD=';1-APR-2008;13:42' -->
<A NAME="page_do48501_1_40"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>businesses
of $1.7&nbsp;million, a $1.4&nbsp;million increase in professional fees, and a $1.0&nbsp;million accrual for the settlement of a class action lawsuit. As a percentage of net revenue,
SG&amp;A expenses decreased 230 basis points to 27.5% in 2006 from 29.8% in 2005 reflecting lower expenses in the wholesale and licensing segments and improved leverage in both our European and retail
segments. The licensing segment included a special performance bonus in 2005 of $4.6&nbsp;million which did not reoccur in 2006. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>EARNINGS FROM OPERATIONS.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Earnings from operations increased $91.2&nbsp;million, or 89.6%, to $193.0&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2006 from $101.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 as a result of improved profitability in all of our segments. The retail segment generated earnings from
operations of $100.4&nbsp;million in 2006 versus earnings from operations of $65.3&nbsp;million in 2005. The increase in earnings from operations for the retail segment was due to higher sales,
improved gross margin and better expense leverage. Earnings from operations for the wholesale segment were $24.0&nbsp;million in 2006 compared to $7.3&nbsp;million in 2005. This increase was
principally due to higher U.S. wholesale sales and gross margin, and lower operating expenses. The European segment increased its earnings from operations to $64.2&nbsp;million in 2006 from
$28.1&nbsp;million in 2005 primarily due
to increased sales, improved gross margin and better expense leverage. Earnings from operations for the licensing segment increased to $57.2&nbsp;million in 2006 from $37.8&nbsp;million in 2005
due primarily to higher revenues generated by our accessories and footwear licensees and lower SG&amp;A costs. The cost of unallocated corporate overhead increased to $52.8&nbsp;million in 2006 from
$36.7&nbsp;million in 2005 mainly due to higher compensation related costs including stock-based compensation expense. The combination of higher sales, increased gross margin and lower SG&amp;A expense
rate resulted in an increase in operating margin of 540 basis points from 10.9% to 16.3%. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>INTEREST EXPENSE AND INTEREST INCOME.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Interest expense increased 10.5% to $7.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006
from $6.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. Total debt at December&nbsp;31, 2006 was $52.4&nbsp;million which comprised approximately $32.9&nbsp;million and
$19.5&nbsp;million of bank debt and capital lease obligations in our European operations, respectively, compared to total debt of $88.3&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2005 which included
$45.9&nbsp;million of European borrowings and $40.7&nbsp;million of the Company's 6.75% Secured Notes. The Secured Notes were redeemed in December 2006 resulting in a $1.4&nbsp;million
write-off of debt issuance costs and a $0.5&nbsp;million redemption premium which are included in interest expense. On a comparable basis, the average debt balance for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2006 was $86.5&nbsp;million, versus an average debt balance of $91.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. Interest income increased to $5.9&nbsp;million
in 2006 from $2.6&nbsp;million in 2005 due to higher average invested cash balances and higher interest rates on this invested cash. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>OTHER INCOME, NET.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Other income was $4.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 versus zero for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2005. Other income in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 was primarily due to gain on the sale of long-term investments, gain on the sale of land, increase in cash
surrender value of long-term investments and unrealized gain from interest rate swap contracts. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>INCOME TAXES.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Income tax for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 was $72.7&nbsp;million, or a 37.1% effective tax rate, compared to
income tax of $38.9&nbsp;million, or a 39.8% effective tax rate, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. The change in the effective tax rate compared to the prior year was due to the lower
impact of permanent tax differences as a result of increased earnings, the generation of capital gains which allowed the Company to realize capital loss carryforwards and favorable tax audit
settlements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>NET EARNINGS.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Net earnings increased by $64.4&nbsp;million, or 109.4%, to $123.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2006, from earnings of $58.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We need liquidity primarily to fund our working capital in Europe, the expansion and remodeling of our retail stores, shop-in-shop
programs, systems, infrastructure, other existing operations, international growth, potential acquisitions, potential share repurchases, and payment of dividends to our shareholders. During the year
ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, the Company relied on trade credit, available cash, short-term </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=43,EFW="2183334",CP="GUESS ?, INC.",DN="1",CHK=637411,FOLIO='40',FILE='DISK108:[08ZAF1.08ZAF48501]DO48501A.;15',USER='ABEAULI',CD=';1-APR-2008;13:42' -->
<A NAME="page_do48501_1_41"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>borrowings
from our European bank facilities, real estate leases and internally generated funds to finance its operations and expansion. The Company anticipates that it will be able to satisfy its
ongoing cash requirements during the next twelve months for working capital, capital expenditures, interest and principal payments on its debt, potential acquisitions, potential share repurchases and
dividend payments to shareholders, primarily with cash flow from operations supplemented by borrowings, if necessary, under the Credit Facility (defined below) and bank facilities in Europe. As of
February&nbsp;2, 2008, the Company had cash and cash equivalents of $275.6&nbsp;million. Excess cash and cash equivalents, which represent the majority of our outstanding cash and cash equivalents
balance, are held primarily in one diversified municipal money market fund. The fund, which is AAA rated, is comprised of high-quality, liquid investments. As of February&nbsp;2, 2008, the Company
does not have any exposure to auction-rate security investments in this fund. Please see "Important Notice Regarding Forward-Looking Statements" for a discussion of risk factors which could reasonably
be likely to result in a decrease of internally generated funds available to finance capital expenditures and working capital requirements. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company has presented below the cash flow performance comparison of the 2008 fiscal year versus the 2007 fiscal year. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Operating Activities  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net cash provided by operating activities was $175.5&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to $141.7&nbsp;million for the year
ended February&nbsp;3, 2007, or an increase of $33.8&nbsp;million. The increase was driven by a $55.3&nbsp;million growth in net income for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008 versus the
prior year period, the increase in non-cash items of $34.3&nbsp;million such as depreciation, share-based compensation expense, deferred taxes and other items. The increase was partially
offset by net investments in working capital including increases in accounts receivable to support growth in Europe and Asia, increases in inventory which were offset by increases in accounts payable,
and the timing of tax payments. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
February&nbsp;2, 2008, the Company had working capital (including cash and cash equivalents) of $426.4&nbsp;million compared to $283.9&nbsp;million at February&nbsp;3, 2007.
The Company's primary working capital needs are for inventory and accounts receivable. Accounts receivable at February&nbsp;2, 2008 amounted to
$254.4&nbsp;million, up $111.7&nbsp;million, compared to $142.7&nbsp;million at February&nbsp;3, 2007. Approximately $57.1&nbsp;million of the increase resulted from the growth in accounts
receivable related to our existing European business, which totaled $141.8&nbsp;million at February&nbsp;2, 2008, versus $84.7&nbsp;million at February&nbsp;3, 2007. Approximately
$69.8&nbsp;million of this $141.8&nbsp;million of European receivables were insured for collection purposes. Our new Focus, BARN, South Korea, Mexico and Greater China operations accounted for
approximately $36.8&nbsp;million of the remaining growth in receivables, of which $13.3&nbsp;million was insured. Currency translation fluctuations accounted for $24.3&nbsp;million of the
increase in accounts receivable. The Company's inventory increased $58.5&nbsp;million to $232.2&nbsp;million at February&nbsp;2, 2008 from $173.7&nbsp;million at February&nbsp;3, 2007.
Approximately $31.0&nbsp;million of this increase was attributed to the Company's new businesses, including Focus, BARN, our new South Korea, Greater China and Mexico operations, and our new G by
GUESS store concept, with the remaining increase driven by our existing North American retail, European and other international operations to support anticipated sales growth in fiscal 2009. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Investing Activities  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net cash used in investing activities increased to $111.9&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to $75.7&nbsp;million for the year
ended February&nbsp;3, 2007, or an increase of $36.2&nbsp;million. The increase in net cash used in investing activities was driven by the opening of 49 new stores in North America during the 2008
fiscal year compared to 33 new stores that were opened in the comparable prior year period, the conversion of 20 stores to the new G by GUESS concept, retail store remodeling programs, expansion in
Europe and Asia, investments in information systems and enhancements in other infrastructure during the 2008 fiscal year. The increase in cash used in investing activities was partially </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>41</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_do48501_1_42"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>offset
by the net proceeds received related to the assignment of an aircraft purchase agreement in fiscal 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Financing Activities  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net cash used in financing activities decreased to $0.1&nbsp;million for the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008, compared to $25.9&nbsp;million for the year
ended February&nbsp;3, 2007, or a decrease of $25.8&nbsp;million. The decrease in net cash used in financing activities was primarily due to the payments relating to the Company's 6.75% secured
notes in the prior year period, partially offset by the payment of cash dividends of $26.3&nbsp;million during the year ended February&nbsp;2, 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Contractual Obligations and Commitments  </B></FONT></P>

and cash flow in future periods (dollars in thousands): </FONT></P>
